sections.name: Introduction
sections.content:
<p>Welcome to the Airbnb API Partner Portal!<annotation> The APIs </annotation>documented here allow you to programmatically:</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>Manage a listing</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Confirm a reservation</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Receive reservation information</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Send and receive messages</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>
<p>Airbnb grants access to the APIs via Scopes on a partner by partner basis. </p>
<p>%{start</p>
<p>You have two options for implementing the first two operations  (<b>manage a listing</b> and <b>confirm a reservation</b>):</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span><b><annotation>XML API</annotation></b> - Upload listing information in a single XML file via one REST API call. You then use the  XML file to manage your listing information.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>REST API</b> - Make multiple REST API calls to create and manage a listing.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>
<p>You need to decide which option to implement. These are mutually exclusive and each requires their own authorization. Confirming reservations is handled differently for each option. </p>
<p>The ability to <b>send and receive messages</b> can be implemented on its own, or in conjunction with these options. The Messaging API is the same whether you choose to use the XML or REST option for managing listings and reservations.</p>

sections.name: Terminology
sections.content:
<p>The following terms are used throughout API Partner Portal documentation:</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span><b>Airbnb Partner Manager </b>— Your Partner Manager helps get you set up to use the API<annotation>.</annotation></span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b><annotation>Host </annotation></b>— The host manages the Airbnb listing and guest experience. The host grants Airbnb account access to the Partner and their application. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Partner Application </b>— The software that uses Airbnb APIs to manage listings on a host's behalf. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Partner </b>— Develops and manages the Partner application. Partners are the target audience for this documentation. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Scopes — </b>Sets of permissions that are granted to a Partner application to access different sets of API functionality. One scope, for example, is needed for the Listing Management XML API and a different one for the Messaging API.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>REST</b> <b>API </b>— Multiple REST APIs for creating and managing a listing.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>XML API </b>— REST API for uploading and managing XML Listing files.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: Basic API Usage Steps
sections.content:
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>Your Airbnb Partner Manager<annotation> approves your application for use.</annotation></span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>At the Airbnb Partner Portal settings page, you<annotation> </annotation>register your application, request scopes (permissions), and register URLs to receive event notifications.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>The host grants the Partner Application permission (via OAuth) <annotation>to access a host account via the API</annotation>. Partner is granted access token to use when making API calls, which you need to refresh on a periodic basis, e.g., daily. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><annotation>Your application should now be set up and, depending on authorization and permissions, be able to</annotation>:</span><br>
</li>
<ul>
<li>
<span>Create and edit listings (listing management)</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Receive reservation requests - booking, cancellation, etc. (reservation management)</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Handle and respond to guest messages (messaging)</span><br>
</li>
</ul>
</ul></div>
<p>For information on registering your application and getting authorization, see our <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default">Getting Started</a> guide.</p>

sections.name: Rate Limiting
sections.content:
<p>To prevent system abuse and ensure API stability, Airbnb enforces several rate limits. Your application is responsible for operating within these rate limits. Once a rate limit has been exceeded, no more requests are handled until the limit expires.</p>
<p>Attempting to issue requests repeatedly beyond the limit could result in your application being blocked for a longer period, other legitimate requests being rejected, and/or the IP address being banned.</p>
<p>If you encounter issues with these limits for your application, please ensure you have taken the following or similar actions:</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>Take a one second delay after every 100 requests. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Build a queuing system to ensure that you dont hit our limits.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Ensure that you do exponential backoff once you hit a rate limit.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Ensure that the you have the User Agent and X-Airbnb-API-Key header on your requests.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: IP Level Rate Limiting
sections.content:
<p>If you see a 503 (Service Unavailable) error, it means that our software has determined that requests from your IP address are abusing the system. The default limits are the following:</p>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Granularity</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span># of requests from a specific IP</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span># of requests from a specific IP to a specific endpoint</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<span>10 seconds</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>200</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>100</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span>5 minutes</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>2,500</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>1,250</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span>1 hour</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>20,000</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>7,500</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span>1 day</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>200,000</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>90,000</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table></div>

sections.name: API Level Rate Limiting
sections.content:
<p>If you receive a 405/429 error you are probably hitting an API specific rate limit. </p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>Airbnb’s API has an overall per limit of 1000 Oauth authentication requests per hour per IP address. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Airbnb’s API has an overall per user rate limit of 2000 calls per hour. This means your application can make 2000 calls per hour for every host who has authorized your application. This limit is shared across all endpoints and if your application exceeds this limit it will result in 429 error. Your calls will then return an error for up to one hour. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Each  API endpoint might have its own specific limit. We describe such limits in their corresponding sections of the documentation.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>
<p>Risk workflows might also add friction to the user. You will see a 420 error code in this case. The best course of action for now is reach out to us and we’ll manually resolve.</p>

sections.name: Listing API Program Policies
sections.content: <p>API partners and hosts should be aware of our program policies.</p>

sections.name: Minimum Listing Standards
sections.content:
<p>The API rejects listings that do not meet the following minimum content requirements.</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>Title - At least 8 characters in the listing title</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Description - At least 50 characters in the listing description field</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Photos - At least 7 photos, including 3 with high-resolution (800x500 pixels) </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Amenities - At least 5 amenities</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: Booking Settings
sections.content:
<p>By default, all API listings are set to Instant Book, with a few exceptions:</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>The reservation dates are shorter than the advance notice requirements for the listing and the host allows Request to Book for shorter notice reservations.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Guest does not meet the requirements set by the host for booking instantly.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>There are specific restrictions on the listing or guest party, e.g. the listing is not suitable for children but the guest's party includes children.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: Regional Policies
sections.content:
<p>The API allows listings in North America, Latin America, Asia, Africa and Europe. However, aside from traditional hospitality listings, we do not currently accept listings via the API in the following select urban markets:</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>New York, NY, USA</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Los Angeles, CA, USA</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Boston, MA, USA</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Portland, OR, USA</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Singapore</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>
<p>Traditional hospitality listings are not subject to these urban market restrictions.</p>
<p>Additionally, in Japan we do not accept listings for accommodations (<i>minpaku</i>) used for Housing Accommodation Business under the Japanese Housing Accommodation Business Act (Act No.65 of 2017) via the API. The only exception to this is certain Japanese API partners who have entered into the license agreement with regard to Airbnb brand and intellectual properties within Japan.</p>

sections.name: Traditional Hospitality Policies
sections.content: <p>We are currently manually reviewing all traditional hospitality listings. This is determined by the property type as described in the <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#creating-a-listing">Property Type Category</a> of the listing management section. The property types which are currently subject to manual review are <annotation><code>aparthotel</code></annotation>, <code>bnb</code>, <code>boutique_hotel</code>, <code>farm_stay</code>, <code>hostel</code>, <code>hotel</code>, <code>lodge</code>, <code>timeshare</code>, <code>minsu</code>, <code>casa_particular</code>, <code>pension</code>, <code>pousada</code>, <code>resort</code>, <annotation><code>ryokan</code></annotation>, <code>heritage_hotel</code>, and <code>serviced_apartment</code>. </p>

sections.name: City Registration Policies
sections.content:
<p>Airbnb has implemented mandatory city registration for several cities such as <a href="https://www.airbnb.com/help/article/1849/san-francisco-s-registration-process--frequently-asked-questions">San Francisco</a>. All listings in those cities will be rejected until the host completes the registration process at <a href="https://airbnb.com/city-registration/#%7Blisting.id%7D/overview">https://airbnb.com/city-registration/{listing_id}/overview</a> for each listing. The registration process requires the host to provide their existing registration details or submit a registration application to the city via Airbnb. </p>
<p><annotation>Listing registration can be completed directly on Airbnb by the host or via the Listings Registration API, which is available for both REST and XML partners.</annotation></p>

sections.name: Room Type Inventory Policies
sections.content:
<p>Room Type inventory allows hosts to have multiple availabilities for the same listing on the same day. Hosts can group multiple rooms into a single “representative” set and use daily availability counts to manage the availability on the listing. </p>
<p>This feature should be implemented only when there is more than 1 room available per day for the listing, and when these rooms share similar attributes such that they can be considered true substitutes; the rooms should have the same amenities, bed configurations, size, decor, and address. </p>
<p>Note that listings with property type House are not eligible to be listed as Room Type Inventory. </p>

sections.name: Hosting Community Standards
sections.content: <p><annotation>Hosts</annotation> are expected to adhere to Airbnb’s community standards. <a href="https://www.airbnb.com/hospitality#commitment">Learn more</a>.</p>

sections.name: Tax Policy
sections.content: <p>Airbnb collects and remits taxes in the regions noted in the <a href="https://airbnb.app.box.com/folder/23799136167"></a><a href="https://airbnb.box.com/s/z055gqr8vfo88e0we0kz80abnc3elovb">TOT Collection &amp; Dates document</a>. For any regions outside of those listed, the host is responsible for complying with in-region guidelines around tax remittance. Most of our Partners have opted to include any taxes t<annotation>hat</annotation> need to be remitted into the listing base price before passing through to Airbnb.</p>

sections.name: Pricing, Availability, and Reservations
sections.content:
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>Hosts must ensure prices and availability are accurate. Hosts are responsible for setting the price.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Airbnb checks pricing and availability immediately before confirming guest reservations. If these conditions change, the reservation is declined with an error to the guest.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>An Airbnb price includes the listing price, cleaning fee, standard fees and optional security deposit. Pricing, and pricing rules and discounts appear to the guest once the guest selects dates.</span><br>
</li>
<ul>
<li>
<span>Airbnb collects taxes in some markets. <a href="https://www.airbnb.com/help/article/653/in-what-areas-is-occupancy-tax-collection-and-remittance-by-airbnb-available?topic=264">Learn more</a>. Taxes that are not collected and remitted by Airbnb should be included in the listing price. Roll any taxes not collected and remitted by Airbnb into the listing price. At this time we do not offer a dedicated tax field.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Cleaning fee is a one-time fee associated with the reservation. An amount equal to cleaning fee  divided by the number of nights in the reservation  is included in the price shown to guests. The cleaning fee is capped at $600 + 25% of the listing price.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>A property manager must make a claim on the security deposit within 14 days of the checkout date or before a new guest checks in, whichever is earlier. <a href="https://www.airbnb.com/resolutions">Submit a claim</a></span><br>
</li>
</ul>
<li>
<span>Price adjustments are applied using our pricing models. Learn more in <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest">Listing Management (REST</a>)  or  <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml">Listing Management (XML)</a></span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Hosts can send Airbnb special offers on the <a href="http://Airbnb.com">Airbnb.com</a> website. If a guest accepts a special offer,  the host gets a normal reservation notification with the pricing sent in the special offer. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>The API does not allow hosts to alter or cancel reservations for now. However, hosts can initiate or confirm changes to reservations on Airbnb.com, and receive notifications via the API.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: Host Service Fees
sections.content: <p>Hosts are charged a service fee (including taxes, if applicable) when a booking is completed. This fee is generally 3%, but may range between 3-5% depending on the host's cancellation policy. The fee is calculated from the booking subtotal (before fees and taxes) and is automatically deducted from the payout to the host.</p>

sections.name: Guest Service Fees
sections.content:
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>When a reservation is confirmed, Guests are charged a service fee between 5% and 15% of the reservation subtotal. Guests see this fee on the checkout page before they book a reservation.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>In areas where collecting VAT is required, the service fee and VAT amounts are combined on the checkout page. Consequently, the service fee may appear to be greater than 15%.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Guest service fees are calculated using a variety of factors including, but not limited to:</span><br>
</li>
<ul>
<li>
<span>The reservation subtotal</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>The reservation length</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Listing characteristics</span><br>
</li>
</ul>
<li>
<span>In general, higher reservation subtotals have lower guest service fee percentages.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: Handling API Changes
sections.content:
<p>Airbnb strives to make all API changes backwards-compatible and does not rename or immediately remove existing documented fields, endpoints, or notifications. However, new fields or functionality might be added; your code should tolerate new fields, but not depend on their existence in the future.</p>
<p>Existing fields or functionality that is being phased out is marked as “<b>deprecated</b>” in the documentation. You should not use these fields. If you are using them, please make plans on discontinuing their use within 1 year, or refer to your partner agreement for specific terms. We will delete documentation for deprecated fields and functionality after 6 months.</p>
<p>Airbnb notifies Partners of all changes via the API Change Log in the Partner Portal. Larger changes will be communicated via email.</p>

sections.name: Changelog
December 13, 2018
sections.content: <p>We have removed Montreal as a market that is restricted by our <a href="/partner/api-docs/overview/default#regional-policies">Listing API Program Policies</a>. You may now publish listings in Montreal via the Listing API.</p>

sections.name: November 15, 2018
sections.content:
<h5 id="listing-categorization-in-france">Listing Categorization in France</h5>
<p>All new listings in France will need to provide a residency category before they can be listed due to local regulatory requirements. The residency category is selected by the host and identifies the listing as a primary residence, a secondary residence or non-residential. We have added the ability for you to provide a listing categorization for French listings in our Listing Regulations API (formerly known as the Listing Registration API). See <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#france-required-fields">France Required Fields</a> for more details.</p>

sections.name: October 15, 2018
sections.content:
<h5 id="special-offers-api">Special offers API</h5>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>We added API functionality to create, withdraw and retrieve Special Offers and pre-approvals via <a href="https://airbnb.com/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#special-offers-api">Special Offers API</a> </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>We added <a href="https://airbnb.com/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#special-offer-updates-notifications">webhook notifications</a> for Special Offer and pre-approval updates. <i>As a reminder, your app should be able to tolerate any new webhook notifications added.</i> We advise you respond with 200 for any webhook notification with an action unknown to your app in order to avoid it being considered a failed notification causing a retry (more info <a href="https://airbnb.com/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#application-response">here</a>) </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>We added <code>special_offer_id</code> field to the <a href="https://airbnb.com/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#reservation-object">Reservation object</a> and <a href="https://admin-next.airbnb.com/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#make-reservation-call">Make Reservation call</a>, so your application is aware that these booking details were confirmed by the host.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: October 11, 2018
sections.content: <p>We've added the ability to provide contact information for either the property manager or the listing owner when submitting registrations and exemptions in Andalusia, Catalonia, and Portugal. The <code>registration_ownership</code> field will now be required on all registration and exemption requests to the <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-regulations-api">Listing Regulations API</a> for Andalusia, Catalonia, and Portugal, and indicates whether the owner or property manager's information is provided.</p>

sections.name: September 21, 2018
sections.content:
<h5 id="los-records">LOS Records</h5>
<p>We have added support for you to set a listing's pricing and availability for specified date/time periods by using a list of length-of-stay records (LOS records). LOS records are an alternative to Seasonal Rule Groups that allow for more flexibility in setting pricing and availability for specific dates and stays. See the documentation for <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#los-records-api">REST</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#xml-los-records">XML</a> for more details on using LOS records.</p>

sections.name: September 10, 2018
sections.content: <p>We have removed Berlin as a restricted market under the <a href="/partner/api-docs/overview/default#regional-policies">Listing API Program Policies</a>. Listings in Berlin can now be published via the Listing API. However, these listings will be subject to a manual review to ensure that they comply with EU Consumer Protection and Unfair Competition Laws, specifically that the host has provided the legally required contact and business information. The host should provide this information prior to publishing listings in the Business Details section of their account settings on Airbnb.</p>

sections.name: August 28th, 2018
sections.content:
<h5 id="guest-requirements">Guest Requirements</h5>
<p>We've added API support for managing Instant Book guest requirements for listings on Everything sync. See the Instant Booking Allowed Category documentation for <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#updating-booking-settings">REST</a> or <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#bookingsettings">XML</a> for more details. Note: Hosts with listings on Limited Sync must manage guests requirements directly on Airbnb.</p>
<h5 id="reservations-api-updates">Reservations API Updates</h5>
<p>Although the Listing API does not support creating listings with a default Request to Book setting, reservations can be Request to Book in certain cases. We've added API support for managing reservation requests for Request to Book reservations. We now send webhook notifications for pending reservation requests and allow accepting or denying pending reservation requests via the API. See the <a href="/partner/api-docs/reservation-management#request-to-book-flow">Request to Book flow</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#accepting-or-denying-a-reservation-request">Accepting or Denying a Reservation Request</a> for more information.</p>
<p>We've also updated the <a href="/partner/api-docs/reservation-management">Reservation Management</a> documentation with more content and diagrams that fully explains the reservation flow.</p>
<p>Finally, we've enabled <a href="/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#setup">Synchronous Availability Checks</a> to be used by XML partners.</p>
<h5 id="listing-regulations-api-updates">Listing Regulations API Updates</h5>
<p>We have added support for a number of markets for our <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-regulations-api">Listing Regulations API</a>: Portugal, Santa Monica, Vancouver, San Francisco and Chicago. You can now submit registration information or exemption information for listings in those markets so that they can be automatically published when they are synced. Now, all markets where listing registration is required on Airbnb are supported by the Listing Regulation API.</p>

sections.name: August 14, 2018
sections.content: <p>We have added support for two new markets for our Listing Regulations API, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#catalonia-required-fields">Catalonia</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#andalusia-required-fields">Andalusia</a>. You can now submit registration information or exemption information for listings in those markets so that they can be automatically published when they are synced. Support for additional markets will be released shortly.</p>

sections.name: August 7, 2018
sections.content: <p>We have relaxed the XML Listing file validation rules when using Limited sync. When syncing only pricing and availability by setting the <code>synchronization_category</code> to <code>"sync_rates_and_availability"</code>, your XML file only needs to contain the <code>pricing</code>, <code>availability</code> and <code>published</code> nodes. All other nodes are no longer required when using Limited sync. The <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#xml-listing-schema">XML Listing Schema</a> has been updated accordingly.</p>

sections.name: July 30, 2018
sections.content:
<h5 id="new-listing-publishing-features">New Listing Publishing Features</h5>
<p>We have made a major update to the section on Publishing a Listing for <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#publishing-a-listing">REST</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#publishing-a-listing">XML</a>. With this update, you have new capabilities when publishing a listing. You can now:</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>set the sync category when creating a new listing so that it is automatically published without the host needing to visit the Sync page.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>connect to an existing listing that is not API-connected via the API without the host needing to visit the sync page.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>sync only pricing and availability data without needing to provide listing content.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>
<p>Additionally, a host using API-connected software can now create new listings manually on the Airbnb website.</p>
<h5 id="listing-regulations-api">Listing Regulations API</h5>
<p>We have released a new REST <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-regulations-api">Listing Regulations API</a>. This API lets you submit the listing regulation information for an Airbnb listing in markets where such information is required by local regulations. To submit listing regulation information, you must provide one of either a listing's existing registration with the market's regulatory body, a valid exemption from listing registration, or listing categorization information. At this time, only Japan is a supported market for the Listing Registration API. Support for other markets will be released shortly.</p>
<h5 id="test-sandbox-for-applications">Test Sandbox for Applications</h5>
<p>We have released a test sandbox for you to test your integration development without affecting the production environment. Each supply partner is now provided with a test application in addition to a production application.</p>
<p>We have added a new <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#notes-on-testing">Notes on Testing</a> section describing how to test your integration using a test application running in our new test sandbox. We have also updated our <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#notes-on-testing">Listing Management Notes on Testing</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#notes-on-testing">Reservation Management Notes on Testing</a> with checklists that you must complete before being granted access to a production application.</p>

sections.name: June 15, 2018
sections.content: <p>For XML partners, new parameters are added for GET request to retrieve <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#listing-import-document-api">Listing Import Documents</a>. It includes <code>reservation_confirmation_code</code> to look up the documents used to confirm that reservation and <code>crawled_before</code> to look up documents created before a particular timestamp.</p>

sections.name: June 4, 2018
sections.content:
<p>We have made two updates to our <a href="/partner/api-docs/overview/default#listing-api-program-policies">Listing API Program Policies</a>.</p>
<h5 id="minimum-listing-standards-2">Minimum Listing Standards</h5>
<p>We have removed the <a href="/partner/api-docs/overview/default#minimum-listing-standards">requirement</a> for a listing to have at least 30 days of availability within a 12-month period.</p>
<h5 id="regional-policies-2">Regional Policies</h5>
<p>We have reduced the number of urban markets where listings are not allowed via the API to <a href="/partner/api-docs/overview/default#regional-policies">7 urban markets</a>.</p>

sections.name: May 7, 2018
sections.content:
<h5 id="room-type-inventory">Room Type Inventory</h5>
<p>We have launched API support for Room Types, which allows multiple rooms to be listed and booked through one Airbnb listing. This functionality simplifies listing management for hosts who manage several rooms with similar layouts. Common use cases for this feature include listing management of boutique hotels, bed &amp; breakfasts and serviced apartments. </p>
<p>Please review our <a href="https://airbnb.com/partner/api-docs/overview/default#room-type-inventory-policies">Room Type Inventory Policies</a> and our <a href="https://airbnb.com/partner/api-docs/overview/default#traditional-hospitality-policies">Traditional Hospitality Policies</a>. </p>
<p>More details can be found in our <a href="https://airbnb.com/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#room-type-inventory">REST</a> and <a href="https://airbnb.com/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#room-type-inventory">XML</a> documentation.</p>
<h5 id="new-strict-cancellation-policy">New Strict Cancellation policy</h5>
<p>Effective immediately, listings with a “Strict” cancellation policy will be automatically converted to “Strict with Grace Period.” This policy allows guests 48 hours after booking to cancel their reservation, up to 14 days before check-in. Guests can cancel this way up to 3 times per year under the policy.  You can find more information on this change <a href="https://community.withairbnb.com/t5/Airbnb-Updates/An-update-on-changes-to-the-Strict-cancellation-policy/m-p/677459#M4850"><u>here</u></a>. Airbnb emailed hosts using the “Strict” cancellation policy about the change on March 21st.</p>
<p><b>What’s the technical change? </b>On the listing level the <code>"strict"</code> value for the cancellation policy is now considered deprecated. You should start passing the new <code>"strict_14_with_grace_period"</code> value. We will continue the write support for the <code>"strict"</code> value in the API for 12 months, but as of today it will be auto-converted to <code>"strict_14_with_grace_period"</code>. Note that on the reservation level, both <code>"strict_14_with_grace_period"</code> and <code>"strict"</code> values are possible (<code>"strict"</code> gets applied if the guest has exhausted their 3 cancellations per year limit).</p>
<p>All reservation webhook notifications and API responses will keep returning <code>"strict"</code> value instead of <code>"strict_14_with_grace_period"</code> <b>until June 27th</b> (even if the new value is passed by you) in order to allow time for you to support the new value in any of the response validations performed by your application. <b>Please update your integration to support this change by June 27th. </b></p>

sections.name: March 15, 2018
sections.content:
<p>We released an important update to our Listing Management APIs. The new APIs allow hosts to participate in Airbnb's <a href="https://www.airbnb.com/host/new">new listing categorization and collections</a>. Not all new fields are displayed to guests yet, as we are in process of collecting information from hosts now. You can expect that updating listing categorization fields will be important for the merchandizing of listings going forward. </p>
<p>Note: Some fields have been deprecated, but existing functionality is backwards compatible.  <b>E</b><annotation><b>verything currently marked as deprecated will be removed from the documentation in 6 months</b></annotation>, and support for those fields will be removed in 12 months.</p>
<h5 id="rest">REST</h5>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span><a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#creating-a-listing">New fields</a> were added to <code>/listings</code>. Now you can provide the <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#property-type-groups">new property type group</a>, the <b>check in option with instructions</b> for confirmed guests and, for private/shared room listings, the information about shared spaces. Some old property types were also deprecated (see the bottom of <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#property-types">the list</a>); you will still be able to write them unless you start passing the property type group.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-rooms-api">New endpoint</a> <code>/listing_rooms</code> was added to provide per <b>room configuration of beds and bathrooms</b>.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#booking-settings-api">New endpoint</a> <code>/booking_settings</code>  was added with new fields like <b>Listing Expectations</b>, <b>Structured House Rules</b> (e.g. suitable for children, smoking allowed, etc.). </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>New <b>parking amenities</b> were added to the list of <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#amenity-strings">supported amenities</a> and some logistics amenities were deprecated in favor of booking settings.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#pricing-settings-api">New endpoint</a> <code>/pricing_settings</code>  was added with new attributes like <b>weekly/monthly price factors</b> and the new <b>Standard Fees</b> (Standard Fees allow you to simplify reporting of fees by mapping each fee to a separate line item. In addition, partners and hosts can get detailed breakdown of fees charged)</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>On top of the above changes, we have deprecated a big chunk of fields on the <code>/listings</code> endpoint and have moved them to the new endpoints to provide logic isolation and better validation errors. </span><br>
</li>
<ul>
<li>
<span>Existing booking setting fields (such as check in/out times, cancellation policy, etc.) were moved to <code>/booking_settings</code>.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Existing pricing fields (such as cleaning fee, extra person fee) were moved to <code>/pricing_settings</code>. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Default min/max nights settings were moved to <code>/availability_rules</code> endpoint.</span><br>
</li>
</ul>
</ul></div>
<h5 id="xml"><annotation>XML</annotation></h5>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span><a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#basicdetails">New fields</a> were added to <code>basicDetails</code> node. Now you can provide: </span><br>
</li>
<ul>
<li>
<span>the <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#property-type-groups">new property type group</a></span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>the <b>check-in option</b> with instructions for confirmed guests</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>shared space information for private/shared room listings</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>[Some old property types were deprecated (see the bottom of <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#property-types">the list</a>); you will still be able to write them unless you start passing the property type group]</span><br>
</li>
</ul>
<li>
<span>New <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#roomconfiguration">room amenities node</a> was added to <code>roomConfiguration</code> node to provide information about <b>ensuite bathrooms for each room</b>.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>New node <code>bookingSettings</code>  was added with new fields: </span><br>
</li>
<ul>
<li>
<span><b>Listing Expectations</b> (e.g. host has pets, potential for noise, etc.)</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Structured Guest Rules</b> (e.g. suitable for children, smoking allowed, etc.).</span><br>
</li>
</ul>
<li>
<span>New <b>parking amenities</b> were added to the list of <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#amenity-strings">supported amenities</a> and some logistics amenities were deprecated in favor of booking settings.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>A new <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#passthroughfees">Standard Fees feature</a> was added<b>. Standard Fees</b> allow you to simplify reporting of fees by mapping each fee to a separate line item. In addition, partners and hosts can get detailed breakdown of fees charged.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: March 12, 2018
sections.content: <p>Added <a href="/partner/api-docs/messaging/default#rate-limits">Rate Limits</a> to Messaging API.</p>

sections.name: February 15, 2018
sections.content: <p>All iCals linked on API-managed listings were removed. iCals are no longer supported once listings become API-managed and in the future will be automatically unlinked.</p>

sections.name: February 13, 2018
sections.content: <p>New field <code>thread_id</code>  was added to <a href="/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#reservation-object">Reservation Object</a> for partners that use <a href="/partner/api-docs/messaging">Messaging API</a>.</p>

sections.name: February 5, 2018
sections.content: <p>For <a href="/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#reservation-object">Reservation Object</a>, <code>cancellation_policy</code> field has been deprecated, please use <code>cancellation_policy_category</code> instead.</p>

sections.name: January 19, 2018
sections.content:
<p>The API documentation set was updated for clarity, accuracy, consistency, and more procedural details and guidance were provided to aid in integration. Some specific changes include:</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>New amenities were added to match what hosts see on Manage Listing page. Any of the old amenities that are now missing should be considered deprecated. You are still able to write them, however you might see inconsistencies on the listing page. We strongly advise all partners implement to the new amenities (<a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#amenity-strings">REST</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#amenity-strings">XML</a>)</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Seasonal Pricing and Availability functionality was added to <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#seasonal-rule-group-api">REST</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#seasonalpricinggroup">XML</a>.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Day of the Week Check In/Out and Day of the Week Min Nights <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#rule-schemas">availability rules</a> were added to REST.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Check-in range functionality was added (<a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#creating-a-listing">REST</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#basicdetails">XML</a>).</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Listings Mapped Notification was deprecated in favor of combined payload in Listing Sync Settings Updated notification (<a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-synchronization-settings-updated">REST</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#listing-synchronization-settings-updated">XML</a>)</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Synchronization category was added to the response (<a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-object">REST</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#listing-import-object">XML</a>)</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>A new auto review filter was added for mandatory City Registration (<a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#api-program-listing-requirements">REST</a> and <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#api-program-listing-requirements">XML</a>)</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>
<blockquote>It is recommended that you review this documentation again, in full, to ensure optimal integration.</blockquote>

sections.name: Technical Support
sections.content: <p>To assist our partners' integration to our API platform, we have a dedicated team of technical support engineers available. This team only supports our Official API Program. Please use the following form to submit requests, <a href="https://airbnb.secure.force.com/contactus/APICaseForm">API Technical Support Request Form</a>.</p>

sections.name: FAQ
sections.content:
<p><b>Should Partner use XML or REST for listings managment?</b></p>
<p>Airbnb offers an “XML API” which is a single REST endpoint for uploading XML Listing files and a “REST API” which is set of multiple REST endpoints to create and manage listings. Partners may select either option depending on their needs. </p>
<p><b>XML API</b></p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>Pro</span><br>
</li>
<ul><li>
<span>Easier to debug and identify schema issues. Each listing corresponds to one XML file.</span><br>
</li></ul>
<li>
<span>Con</span><br>
</li>
<ul><li>
<span>Limited to hourly updates, which may cause content to be temporary out-of-date. Airbnb checks the listing's XML file at the time of booking to avoid double bookings and mis-priced reservations. Partners can also optionally enable real-time checks during booking process to prevent double bookings.</span><br>
</li></ul>
</ul></div>
<p><b>REST API</b></p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>Pro</span><br>
</li>
<ul>
<li>
<span>Allows for near real-time listing management changes</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Allows for near real-time sync during booking process to prevent double bookings</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Allows easier integration with new Airbnb API products</span><br>
</li>
</ul>
<li>
<span>Con</span><br>
</li>
<ul><li>
<span>Requires multiple endpoints to create and manage listings</span><br>
</li></ul>
</ul></div>
<p><b>How often can the Partner application update listing availability?</b></p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>Partner application managing listing availability through the REST API can push availability in real-time, as long as the per second rate limit threshold is not met.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Partner application managing listing availability via XML files can only push hourly updates via the API, though we do initiate an on-demand sync before a booking is confirmed.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>
<p><b>Do we need to build a notifications endpoint and build to the reservation API in order to utilize the API? Will hosts be able to log into Airbnb and see this directly?</b></p>
<p>You must implement and build a complete integration before you can begin sending listings over at scale. Please ensure you are correctly authenticated via OAuth before attempting these calls. See <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default">Getting Started </a>for implementation details.</p>
<p><b>Do I have to upload all of our properties on the test application?</b></p>
<p>There’s no need to upload them all on the test account. If you'd like to test some reservation notifications, please feel free to do so. Once the tests are complete, send the reservation ID over to your Airbnb contact so that they can confirm the cancellation without charges or additional penalties.</p>
<p><b>Does Airbnb allow different rate plans per room?</b></p>
<p>The Airbnb API currently supports one rate plan per property.</p>

sections.name: Document Feedback
sections.content: <p>If you have any feedback on this document, please let us know. We are always interested in learning how we can improve the documentation and the reader's experience. <annotation>Please submit your feedback through the <a href="https://airbnb.secure.force.com/contactus/APICaseForm">API Technical Support Request Form</a>.</annotation></p>

sections.name: Introduction
Test and Production Applications
sections.content:
<p>Airbnb provides supply partners (partners that create, publish, and manage listings) with a test application that runs in a sandbox. Always conduct initial development using your test application. Once the integration of your test application is vetted for completeness and quality, Airbnb will provide you with a production application. Production applications <i>should not</i> be used for testing.  </p>
<p>The test application allows you to create and publish listings that are hidden from real Airbnb guests. It also allows you to assign specific Airbnb accounts to have full view and reservation access to these listings as testers.</p>

sections.name: First Steps
sections.content:
<p>Before your application can begin calling Airbnb APIs on a host's behalf, you need to do the following:</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span><b>Register your app and get credentials</b><br>In a one-time operation, you need to register your application at the Airbnb website and obtain credentials for OAuth 2.0 access. See <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#registering-your-application">Registering Your Application<i>.</i></a></span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Get host authorization<br></b>Each host client needs to authorize your application to act on its behalf. The Airbnb API uses <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OAuth">OAuth 2.0</a> to securely authenticate and access API endpoints. The OAuth 2.0 framework is an Internet standard commonly used to grant access without requiring users to reveal passwords. Handling authorization involves three main steps</span><br>
</li>
<ul>
<li>
<span><a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#initiating-host-authorization">Initiating the authorization process</a> from your application using either the Javascript SDK or a link to the Airbnb authentication flow</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Handling the callback from Airbnb to <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#obtaining-tokens">obtain the initial tokens</a>.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>Continuously <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#managing-tokens">managing tokens</a> to be able to perform authorized API requests.</span><br>
</li>
</ul>
<li>
<span><b>Enable receipt of webhook calls<br></b>You should use Webhook Calls to be notified when an event has occurred, such as a new reservation, a listing being imported, or a guest message. Instead of requiring your application to "pull" information, triggered notifications push account events directly to your app as they occur. The <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#webhook-calls">Webhook Calls</a> section provides details on how you can set up and test notifications.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: Registering Your Application
sections.content: <p>To get started, follow the steps below to set up your application in <a href="/partner/profile/settings">Settings</a>.</p>

sections.name: Application Settings
sections.content:
<p>You need to provide the following to register your application:</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span><b>Application Name </b>— If your application represents a corporation, please include the company name. Note that this is the name displayed on the Airbnb website.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Application Description</b> —  Provide more information about your application.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Email</b> — Your email contact information. </span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Redirect URL </b>— A host is required to authorize your application on Airbnb. The Redirect URL that you provide is called after a host authorizes your application. The URL is invoked with a query string containing a special authorization <code>code</code> that you can use to retrieve access tokens required for all Airbnb API calls. To protect the authorization <code>code</code>, the Redirect URL is required to use a secure connection, i.e., start with <code>https://</code>.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Notification URL </b>— Required to receive <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/#webhook-notifications">Webhook notifications.</a> Please review this section for more details.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Reservation URL </b>— If you are using the REST API for Listing Management, you must include this URL that we use for confirming reservations. Please review <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/#webhook-notifications">Webhook notifications</a> for more details.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Wehbhook Authentication</b> —  On this page, you are also asked to choose either SHA-256 Signature (default) or Basic Authentication<b> </b>for authenticating our webhook requests. Because it is more secure, SHA-256 Signature is recommended. Basic Authentication is easier to implement, but it means that anyone with the username and password can access your server.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>

sections.name: Application Authentication
sections.content:
<p>In the Authentication Tab you can find the following credentials, which are <b>required</b> to get an access token for API calls.</p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span><b>Client ID</b>—Used to identify your application in requests.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span><b>Client Secret</b>—For security, the Client Secret is only available once on this page; you must copy it into a secure location (when obtaining the secret for the first time you should still use the Reset button)</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>
<blockquote>
<b>WARNING:</b> if your Client Secret is leaked, your application security should be considered compromised, and you should immediately reset your Client Secret on this page.</blockquote>

sections.name: Application Scopes
sections.content:
<p>Scopes are sets of permissions that allow your Application to access different endpoints and fields, e.g. <code>messages_write</code> allows you to send messages. Below is the overview of scopes offered by Airbnb:</p>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Scope</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Access</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Included in scopes</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>listings_read</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Read access to <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listings-api">Listings API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-descriptions-api">Listing Descriptions API</a>,<a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#photos-api"> Photos API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-rooms-api">Listing Rooms API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#booking-settings-api">Booking Settings API</a></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span><code>vr</code>, <code>vr_feed</code></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>listings_write</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Write access to <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listings-api">Listings API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-descriptions-api">Listing Descriptions API</a>,<a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#photos-api"> Photos API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#listing-rooms-api">Listing Rooms API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#booking-settings-api">Booking Settings API</a></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span><code>vr</code></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>calendars_read</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Read access to <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#availability-rules-api">Availability Rules API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#pricing-settings-api">Pricing Settings API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#calendars-api">Calendars API</a></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span><code>vr</code></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>calendars_write</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Write access to <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#availability-rules-api">Availability Rules API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#pricing-settings-api">Pricing Settings API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#calendars-api">Calendars API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/rest#calendar-batch-operations-api">Calendar Operations API</a></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span><code>vr</code></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>reservations_read</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Read access to <a href="/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#reservations-api">Reservations API</a>,  confirmed reservations Webhooks.</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span><code>vr</code>, <code>vr_feed</code></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>reservations_write</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Write access to <a href="/partner/api-docs/reservation-management/default#reservations-api">Reservations API</a></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span><code>vr</code>, <code>vr_feed</code></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>reservations_web_hooks</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Synchronous Availability Checks</span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span><code>vr</code></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>listing_import_management</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Full access to<a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#listing-import-api"> Listing Import API</a>, <a href="/partner/api-docs/listing-management/xml#listing-import-document-api">Listing Import Documents API</a></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span><code>vr_feed</code></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>messages_read</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Read access to <a href="/partner/api-docs/messaging/default#message-and-thread-api">Messages and Thread API</a></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>messages_write</code></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Write access to <a href="/partner/api-docs/messaging/default#message-and-thread-api">Messages and Thread API</a></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span></span><br>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table></div>
<p>First, you application is granted a set of scopes by Airbnb, that can be added/removed in the future. We call these <b>Application Level Scopes</b>. You can manage these scopes in the Scopes tab of the Partner Portal.</p>
<p>You can use all of your application scopes or just a subset to request an authorization from the host. We call this set of scopes, that a host has authorized you for, <b>Authorization Level Scopes.</b></p>
<h5 id="adding-scopes">Adding Scopes</h5>
<p>When you request additional Application scopes in the Scopes Tab, Airbnb either approves or rejects your request. Please use the <a href="https://airbnb.secure.force.com/contactus/APICaseForm">API support form</a> to ask for your request to be approved.</p>
<p>Once your new scopes are approved, all existing authorizations remain unchanged. You are not automatically authorized to use the new scopes for any of the existing host authorizations. You still need to obtain a new authorization with a new set of Authorization Level Scopes for each host<b>.</b> The process of adding these is similar to the initial authorization process: </p>
<div><ul>
<li>
<span>You request the host to authorize your application for these new scopes (note that including any of the old scopes will cause the operation to fail)</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>After the host has authorized your application we call your redirect URL with a new code.</span><br>
</li>
<li>
<span>You use the code to obtain a new set of refresh and access tokens for this host. All your previous tokens are no longer valid.</span><br>
</li>
</ul></div>
<blockquote>Only one of <code>vr</code> or <code>vr_feed</code> scopes can be used for Authorization level scopes.</blockquote>

sections.name: Testing Best Practices
sections.content:
<p>When registering your test application, include the word 'test' in the name field, so everyone knows it's for testing, e.g. 'Bookingbear Test'.</p>
<p>Make sure to complete all the fields, including redirect, webhook, and reservation notification URLs for your application. These enable you to test authorization, publishing, and the reservation lifecycle.</p>

sections.name: Initiating Host Authorization
sections.content:
<p>Each host client utilizing your application needs to authorize it. In this step, you need to create an HTML page on your Website or mobile app containing a "connect" button that, when clicked, takes the host to the Airbnb website where they are given the option to allow or deny your application access on their behalf.  For convenience, Airbnb provides a simple JavaScript SDK you can use for this step. The SDK displays the button that redirects the host to authorize your application. </p>
<p>Alternatively, you can build your own integration without the JavaScript SDK. See  <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#authorizing-without-the-javascript-sdk">Authorizing Without the JavaScript SDK</a>.</p>

sections.name: Authorizing With the JavaScript SDK
sections.content:
<p>JavaScript integration is a two-step process:</p>
<h5 id="link-to-the-sdk"><b>Link to the SDK</b></h5>
<p>First, include the following in your HTML:</p>
<pre class="highlight html"><code><span class="nt">&lt;script </span><span class="na">src=</span><span class="s">"https://www.airbnb.com/platform_js"</span> <span class="na">async</span> <span class="na">defer</span><span class="nt">&gt;&lt;/script&gt;</span></code></pre>
<p>The <code>async</code> and <code>defer</code> attributes allow the script to be loaded asynchronously. They are optional, but recommended.</p>
<h5 id="add-an-html-authorization-button"><b>Add an HTML Authorization Button</b></h5>
<p>To specify where the button appears on the page, use the following HTML:</p>
<pre class="highlight html"><code><span class="nt">&lt;span</span> <span class="na">class=</span><span class="s">"airbnb-connect"</span>
      <span class="na">data-client-id=</span><span class="s">"9ffd99sfv853bsvvs"</span>
      <span class="na">data-scope=</span><span class="s">"vr,messages_read"</span>
      <span class="na">data-redirect-uri=</span><span class="s">"https://example.com/airbnb"</span>
<span class="nt">&gt;&lt;/span&gt;</span></code></pre>
<p>The attributes currently supported are:</p>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Attribute</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Description</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>data-client-id</code> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Your Client ID retrieved from the Developer Console.</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>data-redirect-uri</code> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Your Redirect URL entered when registering your app. This is where a host is redirected to when they click the <code>connect</code> button</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>data-scope</code> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>A comma-separated string or required scopes, e.g., <code>vr_feed</code> (XML) or <code>vr </code>(REST). </span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>data-state</code><br><u>optional</u></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>This field is one string. Values set here are mirrored in the URL parameters of the redirect URL. You can use this, for example, to identify fake authorization requests, and also useful to piggy-back some session-dependent value for an app to complete an authorization transaction.</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>data-width</code><br><u>optional</u></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Button width. Default= <code>189px</code>.</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span><code>data-height</code><br><u>optional</u></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Button height. Default= <code>34px</code>.</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table></div>
<p>When your host clicks this button, they are taken to the Airbnb website where they are given the opportunity to allow or deny your application access. If allowed, you are sent an authorization <code>code</code> via the Redirect URL that you registered with your application.</p>
<p><b>Dynamically Adding the Airbnb Button </b></p>
<p>The JavaScript SDK scans the page for DOM elements with the <code>airbnb-connect</code> class, and injects buttons at those points in the markup. By default, this happens when the page loads. Additionally, you may dynamically insert the button markup, e.g. in response to UI events or AJAX requests. If you do so, you must tell the SDK to scan the page again. You can do that in JavaScript as follows:</p>
<pre class="highlight js"><code><span class="nb">window</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">airbnb</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">bootstrap</span><span class="p">();</span></code></pre>

sections.name: Authorizing Without the JavaScript SDK
sections.content:
<p>From within a <b>host's browser</b>, you can also authorize the application using a GET request to the following URL:</p>
<pre class="highlight text"><code>https://www.airbnb.com/oauth2/auth?client_id=:your_client_id&amp;redirect_uri=:your_redirect_url&amp;scope=:your_scope&amp;state=:whatever_you_want</code></pre>
<p>The query param values correspond to the parameters in the attributes table under Step 2 above. As described in that table, the <code>state</code> param is optional.</p>

sections.name: Authorizing With a Mobile App
sections.content:
<p><b>Button Snippet for iOS and Android</b></p>
<p>These snippets are the button presentation on iOS and Android.</p>
<p><b>iOS</b></p>
<pre class="highlight objc"><code><span class="n">UIButton</span> <span class="o">*</span><span class="n">button</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">UIButton</span> <span class="nf">buttonWithType</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="n">UIButtonTypeCustom</span><span class="p">];</span>
<span class="n">button</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">layer</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">cornerRadius</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span>
<span class="n">button</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">contentEdgeInsets</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">UIEdgeInsetsMake</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">f</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">f</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">f</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">f</span><span class="p">);</span>
<span class="p">[</span><span class="n">button</span> <span class="nf">setTitleColor</span><span class="p">:[</span><span class="n">UIColor</span> <span class="nf">whiteColor</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="nf">forState</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="n">UIControlStateNormal</span><span class="p">];</span>
<span class="n">button</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">backgroundColor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">UIColor</span> <span class="nf">colorWithRed</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="mo">000</span> <span class="nf">green</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="mi">353</span> <span class="n">blue</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="mi">373</span> <span class="n">alpha</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">];</span>
<span class="n">button</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">alpha</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">;</span>
<span class="p">[</span><span class="n">button</span> <span class="nf">setTitle</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s">@"Connect with Airbnb"</span> <span class="nf">forState</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="n">UIControlStateNormal</span><span class="p">];</span>
<span class="n">button</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">frame</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">CGRectMake</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">view</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">bounds</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">size</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">width</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">32</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">50</span><span class="p">);</span>
<span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">button</span><span class="p">;</span></code></pre>
<p><b>Android</b></p>
<pre class="highlight config"><code><span class="n">android</span>:<span class="n">textSize</span>=<span class="s2">"20sp"</span>
<span class="n">android</span>:<span class="n">layout_height</span>=<span class="s2">"48dp"</span>
<span class="n">android</span>:<span class="n">layout_width</span>=<span class="s2">"match_parent"</span>
<span class="n">android</span>:<span class="n">background</span>=<span class="s2">""</span> // <span class="n">see</span> <span class="n">details</span> <span class="n">below</span>
<span class="n">android</span>:<span class="n">alpha</span>=<span class="s2">"0.9"</span>
<span class="n">android</span>:<span class="n">padding</span>=<span class="s2">"5dp"</span>
<span class="n">android</span>:<span class="n">textColor</span>=<span class="s2">"@color/white"</span>
<span class="n">android</span>:<span class="n">gravity</span>=<span class="s2">"center"</span></code></pre>
<p>The background is defined by a disabled, pressed and default color. These are the colors:</p>
<pre class="highlight text"><code>disabled = #f8b9bb
pressed = #ff7a7f
default = #FF5A5F</code></pre>

sections.name: Obtaining Tokens
Handling the Authorization Response
sections.content:
<p>After a host grants or denies your application access, your server must handle the authorization response via a redirect Airbnb issues the host. This response contains a <code>code</code> field which you can use to get an initial access token.</p>
<blockquote>
<b>WARNING:</b> For security, your authorization <code>code</code> expires in 24 hrs after its first use.</blockquote>
<p>Example success redirect response, including an authorization <code>code</code>:</p>
<pre class="highlight text"><code>https://www.YOURDOMAIN.com/?code=3ygawaklwqt5ottmghf9l0xi6&amp;scope=vr+messages_read&amp;state=custom_state1234</code></pre>
<p>or</p>
<pre class="highlight text"><code>https://www.YOURDOMAIN.com/?code=3ygawaklwqt5ottmghf9l0xi6&amp;scope=vr_feed&amp;state=custom_state1234</code></pre>
<p>In the above examples, you need to save the <code>code=3ygawaklwqt5ottmghf9l0xi6</code> field for next steps.</p>
<p>Example failure redirect response when the user denied the application access, including the error and an error description:</p>
<pre class="highlight text"><code>https://www.YOURDOMAIN.com/?error=access_denied&amp;error_description=The+user+denied+you+access&amp;state=custom_state1234&amp;gws_rd=ssl</code></pre>

sections.name: Exchanging Code for Tokens
sections.content:
<p>After making a successful request, you can exchange the provided authorization <code>code</code> for an access token and a refresh token via a server-to-server <code>POST</code> call.</p>
<pre class="highlight text"><code>POST /v2/oauth2/authorizations?_unwrapped=true</code></pre>
<blockquote>
<b>WARNING:</b> The refresh token is <b>very important</b>; to renew your access token for API calls requires a refresh token. <b>Make sure you store this in a secure location! </b>If you misplace your refresh token, you will have to start over and go through the authorization process again.</blockquote>
<h5 id="request-headers">Request Headers</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Header</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Description</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody><tr>
<td>
<span><code>Authorization</code> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>The Client ID and Secret retrieved from the Developer Console, formatted for Basic Auth. For more information, see <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#formatting-a-basic-auth-header">Formatting a Basic Auth Header</a>. </span><br>
</td>
</tr></tbody>
</table></div>
<h5 id="request-url-parameters">Request URL parameters</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Param</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Description</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody><tr>
<td>
<span><code>_unwrapped</code> <br> <i>boolean</i> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Use <code>true</code> for the OAuth2-spec-compliant format.</span><br>
</td>
</tr></tbody>
</table></div>
<h5 id="request-body-parameters">Request Body Parameters</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Parameter</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Description</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody><tr>
<td>
<span><code>code</code> <br> <i>string</i> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>The string received from the redirect URL in the previous authorization step</span><br>
</td>
</tr></tbody>
</table></div>
<h5 id="example-request">Example Request</h5>
<p>Request example using cURL's automatic Base64 encoding of <code>-u</code> option strings:</p>
<pre class="highlight bash"><code>curl -X POST <span class="se">\ </span>
-d <span class="s1">'{ "code": "3ygawaklwqt5ottmghf9l0xi6" }'</span> <span class="se">\</span>
-H <span class="s1">'Content-Type: application/json'</span> <span class="se">\</span>
-u <span class="s1">'4n764q9f97ai0wwz9veq23e4u:7hx9qmsdfdasf246en5ja5'</span> <span class="se">\</span>
https://api.airbnb.com/v2/oauth2/authorizations?_unwrapped<span class="o">=</span><span class="nb">true</span></code></pre>
<h5 id="example-response">Example Response</h5>
<pre class="highlight json"><code><span class="p">{</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"access_token"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"40xdf4fvdotrpnwv6tkuroaze"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"expires_at"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="mi">1422594787</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"refresh_token"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"d1gwltceepbiouw6dznxpf7k2"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"user_id"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="mi">1603070</span><span class="w">
</span><span class="p">}</span></code></pre>

sections.name: Making the first API request
sections.content:
<p>After exchanging the authorization <code>code</code> for tokens, you can make requests to Airbnb API. Make a call to the <code>/v2/users/me</code> endpoint to return the token owner's user object. Ensure you pass <code>X-Airbnb-API-Key</code> and <code>X-Airbnb-OAuth-Token</code> into the Header, as all API requests will require these two values.</p>
<pre class="highlight text"><code>GET /v2/users/me</code></pre>
<h5 id="request-headers-2">Request Headers</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Header</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Description</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<span>X-Airbnb-API-Key <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>The Client ID from Settings &gt; Authentication</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<span>X-Airbnb-OAuth-Token<br><b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>The <code>access_token</code> you received by exchanging the authorization <code>code</code>.</span><br>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table></div>
<h5 id="example-request-2">Example Request</h5>
<pre class="highlight bash"><code>curl -X <span class="s2">"GET"</span> <span class="s2">"https://api.airbnb.com/v2/users/me"</span> <span class="se">\</span>
  -H <span class="s1">'X-Airbnb-API-Key:cgdrdjfv4hvzptgcax0ncplnf'</span> <span class="se">\</span>
  -H <span class="s1">'X-Airbnb-OAuth-Token:12taga7tyfzgm3bf73fwaq0e2'</span> <span class="se">\</span>
  -H <span class="s2">"Content-Type: application/json"</span></code></pre>
<h5 id="example-response-2">Example response</h5>
<pre class="highlight json"><code><span class="p">{</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"user"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p">{</span><span class="w">
    </span><span class="nt">"email"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"chuck.norris@airbnb.com"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
    </span><span class="nt">"first_name"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"Chuck"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
    </span><span class="nt">"id"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="mi">747667747</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
    </span><span class="nt">"last_name"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"Norris"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
    </span><span class="nt">"managed_business_entity_id"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">null</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
    </span><span class="nt">"phone"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"+1 (555) 667-7475"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
    </span><span class="nt">"picture_url"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"https://a0.muscache.com/im/pictures/user/cbs4d8dm-3dm9-0dxk-887e-2jd9eikemach9.jpg?aki_policy=profile_x_medium"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
    </span><span class="nt">"picture_url_large"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"https://a0.muscache.com/im/pictures/user/cbs4d8dm-3dm9-0dxk-887e-2jd9eikemach9.jpg?aki_policy=profile_large"</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="p">},</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"metadata"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p">{}</span><span class="w">
</span><span class="p">}</span></code></pre>
<p>If you received a user object response, then you have successfully authorized the host with your application, retrieved tokens, and made your first API request.</p>

sections.name: Managing Tokens
sections.content:
<p>The operations below describe how you can check the status, refresh or revoke the tokens.</p>
<p>We recommend that, during normal operation, before refreshing an access token, you check to see if it is still valid (using the <code>expires_at</code> field or by <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#checking-token-status">Checking Token Status</a><i> </i>below). Refreshing a token before each API call might cause race conditions.</p>

sections.name: Checking Token Status
sections.content:
<p>You can use this endpoint to check a token's status and determine if it needs to be refreshed.</p>
<pre class="highlight text"><code>GET /v2/oauth2/authorizations/:token?_unwrapped=true</code></pre>
<h5 id="request-headers-3">Request Headers</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Header</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Description</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody><tr>
<td>
<span><code>Authorization</code> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>The Client ID and Secret retrieved from the Partner Portal, formatted for Basic Auth. For more information, see <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#formatting-a-basic-auth-header">Formatting a Basic Auth Header</a>.</span><br>
</td>
</tr></tbody>
</table></div>
<h5 id="request-url-id">Request URL ID</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Parameter</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Value</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody><tr>
<td>
<span><code>token</code> <br> <i>string</i></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Either an access or refresh token for this user.</span><br>
</td>
</tr></tbody>
</table></div>
<h5 id="request-url-parameters-2">Request URL parameters</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Parameter</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Description</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody><tr>
<td>
<span><code>_unwrapped</code> <br> <i>boolean</i> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Use <code>true</code> for the OAuth2-spec-compliant format.</span><br>
</td>
</tr></tbody>
</table></div>
<h5 id="example-request-3">Example Request</h5>
<p>Example cURL request using cURL's automatic Base64 encoding of -u option strings:</p>
<pre class="highlight bash"><code>curl <span class="se">\</span>
  -u <span class="s1">'4n764q9f97ai0wwz9veq23e4u:7hx9qmsdfdasf246en5ja5'</span> <span class="se">\</span>
  https://api.airbnb.com/v2/oauth2/authorizations/d1gwltceepbiouw6dznxpf7k2?_unwrapped<span class="o">=</span><span class="nb">true</span></code></pre>
<h5 id="example-invalid-response">Example Invalid Response</h5>
<pre class="highlight json"><code><span class="p">{</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"token"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"1pgmj4c0yi1j20aajn5wl0fw"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"token_type"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"access_token"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"user_id"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="mi">18890019</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"valid"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">false</span><span class="w">
</span><span class="p">}</span></code></pre>
<h5 id="example-valid-response">Example Valid Response</h5>
<pre class="highlight json"><code><span class="p">{</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"expires_at"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="mi">1422595153</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"token"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"e8ef4q56gf840g3vnnobub4a5"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"token_type"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">"access_token"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"user_id"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="mi">1603070</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w">
  </span><span class="nt">"valid"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w">
</span><span class="p">}</span></code></pre>

sections.name: Refreshing a Token
sections.content:
<p>For security purposes, an access token is always short-lived — currently 24 hours but subject to change. This means you need to get a new access token, usually daily, to continue using the APIs. This requires making a call using your saved refresh token.</p>
<blockquote>Once you refresh a token, the original authorization <code>code</code> is invalid and cannot be used again.</blockquote>
<pre class="highlight text"><code>POST /v2/oauth2/authorizations?_unwrapped=true</code></pre>
<h5 id="request-headers-4">Request Headers</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Header</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Description</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody><tr>
<td>
<span><code>Authorization</code> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>The Client ID and Secret retrieved from the Developer Console, formatted for Basic Auth. For more information, see <a href="/partner/api-docs/get-started/default#formatting-a-basic-auth-header">Formatting a Basic Auth Header</a>.</span><br>
</td>
</tr></tbody>
</table></div>
<h5 id="request-url-parameters-3">Request URL parameters</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
<span>Parameter</span><br>
</th>
<th>
<span>Description</span><br>
</th>
</tr></thead>
<tbody><tr>
<td>
<span><code>_unwrapped</code> <br> <i>boolean</i> <br> <b><i>required</i></b></span><br>
</td>
<td>
<span>Use <code>true</code> for the OAuth2-spec-compliant format.</span><br>
</td>
</tr></tbody>
</table></div>
<h5 id="request-body-parameters-2">Request Body Parameters</h5>
<div><table>
<thead><tr>
<th>
